translated: Even if it is established, that different object is not established as the object.

analyzed: viṣayīkartum aśakya tvāt iti tat api
translated: Because that different [object] cannot be made an object by a consciousness with form or without form, which is meaningful. Therefore, that [object]

analyzed: sva ākāra ātmakam eva vedyam sidhyati iti yat uktam
translated: is also established as only knowable in the form of itself. What was said:

analyzed: buddhi pūrvām kriyām dṛṣṭvā tad grahāt
translated: Having seen activity preceded by consciousness in one's own body, from the understanding of that in another,

original: jñāyate yadi dhīścittamātre'pyeṣa nayaḥ samaḥ // iti /
analyzed: jñāyate yadi dhīḥ cittamātra ipi eṣa nayaḥ samaḥ iti
translated: if consciousness is known, this method is the same even in mere mind.

analyzed: tat api ayuktam iti atas kaḥ kasya kim kuryāt iti
translated: That is also incorrect. Therefore, who does what for whom?

analyzed: sarva vyavahāra abhāva prasaṅgaḥ tatas satya bhūtaḥ eva
translated: There would be the consequence of the absence of all conventions. Therefore, [consciousness] is truly existent.

analyzed: grāhya grāhaka bhedaḥ abhyupagantavyaḥ iti anivartya tvāt advaya asiddhe
translated: The distinction between the apprehended object and the apprehending subject must be accepted. Thus, because it cannot be averted, non-duality is not established.

analyzed: ra nirmokṣaḥ eva bhavatām
translated: Therefore, for you, there is no liberation at all.

analyzed: adhunā yaiḥ bāhyam abhyupagamya sa ākāram eva tasya grāhakam iṣyate
translated: Now, for those who accept external objects and consider the apprehender to have a form,

analyzed: artha jñānayoḥ ākāra bhedam na upalabhāmahe iti vadadbhiḥ tān pratyucyate
translated: who say We do not perceive a difference in form between the object and cognition, it is said to them:

analyzed: saṅgupta karaṇasya iha yoginaḥ buddhi paddhatiḥ
translated: Here, for the yogi whose senses are withdrawn, the path of the intellect

analyzed: apāsta viṣaya ākārā dṛṣṭā tasmāt pratīyate
translated: Is seen to be devoid of the forms of external objects. Therefore, it is understood.

analyzed: śabda ādi viṣayaḥ yaḥ api bodhaḥ saḥ upi a tad ākṛtiḥ
translated: Even the cognition of sound and other objects does not have that form.

analyzed: tad pariccheda rūpā asau tad ākāraḥ iti bhramaḥ
translated: It is the form of its delimitation. The error is that it has that form.

analyzed: bhavet etat yadi artha jñānayoḥ ākāra bhedaḥ na upalabdhaḥ bhavet sa
translated: This would be so if the difference in form between the object and cognition were not perceived.

original: tūpalabhyata eva / tathā hi samupahṛtasamastakaraṇavṛtterata eva
analyzed: tu upalabhyate eva tathā hi samupahṛta samasta karaṇa vṛtteḥ atas eva
translated: But it is indeed perceived. Thus, for one whose functioning of all the senses is withdrawn,

analyzed: vinivṛtta akhila viṣaya ākāra vedanasya saṃvid mātra yoginaḥ śuddham eva
translated: and whose experience of all forms of external objects has ceased, who is united only with consciousness, the form of the pure

analyzed: vijñāna ātma rūpam prabandhena prakāśate iti bhavat āgame pi
translated: cognizant self shines forth continuously. Thus, even in your scriptures,

analyzed: dṛṣṭam advayasya artha an ārūpitasya anyathā prāpti asambhavāt
translated: Because it is seen that the non-dual object, which is not modified, cannot be apprehended in any other way.

analyzed: ca adhyātma kuśalaiḥ api
translated: And it has been said by those skilled in the inner sciences as well:

analyzed: tadā draṣṭuḥ sva rūpa iva sthānam iti
translated: Then there is the abiding of the seer in its own nature.

analyzed: arthakārāt bhinnaḥ eva grāhakaḥ siddhaḥ tatas bhedāt eva
translated: The apprehender is established as being different from the object-cause itself, because of that difference.

analyzed: śabda ādi pariccheda kāle tad pariccheka tvam eva
translated: At the time of the discrimination of sound etc., the nature of the apprehender is only to be discriminated,

analyzed: grāhaka ātmanaḥ anubhava siddha tvāt pratyetum śakyam na tu
translated: because it is established by experience. But it cannot be experienced

analyzed: śabda ādi ākāra rūpa tā anubhava virodhāt iti sa ākāra pakṣaḥ api bhramaḥ eva
translated: as having the form of sound etc., because that would contradict experience. Therefore, the view of having an image is also just an error.

analyzed: etat eva ghaṭayan āha
translated: Establishing this very [view], he says:

original: artha eva hi sākāro yatastadvān sa gṛhyate /🔽artho hi anekanīlapītādyākārabhedabhinno grāhakātmanaḥ🔽pratyagrūpeṇādhyātmamanubhūyamānāt purorūpatvena
analyzed: arthaḥ eva hi sa ākāraḥ yatas tadvān sa gṛhyate  arthaḥ hi aneka nīla pīta ādi ākāra bheda bhinnaḥ grāhaka ātmanaḥ  pratyak rūpeṇa adhyātmam anubhūyamānāt puras rūpa tvena
translated: For the object itself has an image, since the possessor of that is apprehended.🔽For the object, which is differentiated by the various images such as blue, yellow, etc., is experienced internally by the nature of the apprehender🔽in the form of the present moment, and is cognized externally as having an image, connected with a distant place. Thus it is proper that [the object] is different

original: bahirdeśasambaddhaḥ sākāra eva vedyate / iti tato'nākārājjñānādbhinna🔽eva yuktaḥ /
analyzed: bahis deśa sambaddhaḥ sa ākāraḥ eva vedyate iti tatas na ākārāt jñānāt bhinna  eva yuktaḥ
translated: from the cognition which has no image.

analyzed: evam grāhaka ātma apekṣayā uktvā adhyavasāya apekṣayā api āha
translated: Having thus spoken from the perspective of the apprehending self, he also says from the perspective of determination:

original: pūrvaṃ ca gṛhyate vastu bodhaḥ paścāditi sthitiḥ // //
analyzed: pūrvam ca gṛhyate vastu bodhaḥ paścāt iti sthitiḥ
translated: And it is established that the object is apprehended first, and cognition afterwards.

analyzed: jhaṭiti indriya artha saṃyoge hi prathamam adhyavasāya rahitam
translated: For when there is an immediate contact of sense and object, the pure thing itself is first apprehended without any determination,

original: śuddhameva vastu / paścāttu ghaṭo'yam ityādyadhyavasāyo'pi saṃvedyata
analyzed: śuddham eva vastu paścāt tu ghaṭaḥ yam ityādi adhyavasāya upi saṃvedyata
translated: but afterwards the determination 'this is a jar' is also experienced.

original: iti tadabhedo'pyayuktaḥ / nanu buddhyavasitamarthaṃ puruṣaścetayate / iti
analyzed: iti tad abheda upya yuktaḥ nanu buddhi avasitam artham puruṣaḥ cetayate iti
translated: Therefore their non-difference is also improper. But surely the soul cognizes the object determined by the intellect. Thus

original: sarveṣāṃ buddhipuruṣavivekavādināmabhyupagamaḥ / tataḥ🔽pūrvamadhyavasāyaḥ paścātsaṃvedanamiti bhavatāṃ sthitiryuktā na
analyzed: sarveṣām buddhi puruṣa viveka vādinām abhyupagamaḥ tatas  pūrvam adhyavasāyaḥ paścāt saṃvedanam iti bhavatām sthitiḥ yuktā na
translated: it is accepted by all who maintain the distinction of intellect and soul. Therefore

analyzed: tu iyam śākya darśana paridṛṣṭā iti satyam smṛti pratibhāsa ādau eva asau na
translated: the position that determination comes first and cognition afterwards is proper for you, but this is not seen in the Śākya doctrine. True, it is only in memory and imagination that this occurs,

original: sarvatrānubhavavirodhāt / nahi pratidarśanamanubhavabhedo / yuktastasya🔽vastusiddhatvāt nahi nīlaṃ śākyānāmeva nīlamārhatānāṃ tu pītamiti
analyzed: sarvatra anubhava virodhāt nahi pratidarśanam anubhava bhedaḥ yuktaḥ tasya  vastu siddha tvāt nahi nīlam śākyānām eva nīlam ārhatānām tu pītam iti
translated: not everywhere, because it contradicts experience. For the difference of experience in every cognition is not proper,

original: śakyamatinipuṇatarairapi vaktum / anubhavo hyayaṃ vastusāmarthyasiddhaḥ🔽prathamamanadhyavasāyātmaka eva saṃvedyamānaḥ kathamanyathā
analyzed: śakyam ati nipuṇataraiḥ api vaktum anubhavaḥ hi ayam vastu sāmarthya siddhaḥ  prathamam anadhyavasāya ātmakaḥ eva saṃvedyamānaḥ katham anyathā
translated: because that is established by the thing itself. For it is not possible for the very clever ones to say that blue is blue only for the Śākyas, but yellow for the Jains.🔽For this experience is established by the power of the thing itself.

analyzed: vyavasthāpayitum śakyaḥ yat āhuḥ
translated: How else can it be established if it is first experienced as having the nature of non-determination? As they say:

analyzed: asti hi ālocanam jñānam prathamam nirvikalpakam
translated: For there is first a non-conceptual cognition, which is perception.

analyzed: bāla mūka ādi vijñāna sadṛśam śuddha vastu jam  tatas pram punar vastu dharmaiḥ jāti ādibhiḥ yayā
translated: Like the cognition of a child or a mute, it arises from a pure object.🔽Then, the object is again determined by the intellect through its qualities such as genus, etc.

analyzed: buddhyā avasīyate sā api pratyakṣa tvena sammatā
translated: That [cognition] is also accepted as perception.

analyzed: iti yuktam uktam iti sthitiḥ iti
translated: Thus it is rightly said, this is the established position.

analyzed: nanu nā akāraṇam viṣayaḥ jñānasya anavasthā prasaṅgāt kāraṇa tve
translated: But the object is not the cause of cognition, because of the fallacy of infinite regress. If it were the cause,

analyzed: ca indriya ādeḥ api prasaṅgāt tad ākāra tā eva yuktā iti āha
translated: then the sense organ would also be the cause. It is proper to say that [cognition] has the form of that [object]. Thus he says:

analyzed: vastunaḥ janaka tvam hi biddhim pratyupakāri tā
translated: The production of an object is its helpfulness to cognition.

original: karmatendriyasambandhādādānaṃ nākṛterataḥ // //🔽buddhiṃ prati vastuno janakatvamupakāritvaṃ karmatā
analyzed: karmatā indriya sambandhāt ādānam na ākṛteḥ atas  buddhim prati vastunaḥ janaka tvam upakāri tvam karmatā
translated: The grasping is due to the connection with the object, not due to having the same form.

original: grāhyatvamevocyate yataḥ / tato na tadākārādānamupapadyate /🔽nāpyanavasthetyāha indriyasambandhāt / grāhyatvāviśeṣe'pi
analyzed: grāhya tvam eva ucyate yatas tatas na tad ākāra ādānam upapadyate  na api anavasthā iti āha indriya sambandhāt grāhya tva aviśeṣe api
translated: The production of an object is said to be its helpfulness, its being an object, its being graspable, in relation to cognition. Therefore, grasping its form is not logically possible.🔽Nor is there an infinite regress. He says this because of the connection with the sense organ. Even though there is no difference in being graspable,

original: yadevendriyasambaddhaṃ vastu tadeva gṛhyate nānyat yataḥ / taduktam
analyzed: yat eva indriya sambaddham vastu tat eva gṛhyate na anyat yatas tat uktam
translated: only that object which is connected with the sense organ is apprehended, not another, because of this. This is stated:

original: satsamprayoge puruṣasyendriyāṇāṃ buddhijanma tat pratyakṣam /🔽iti / ato nirākārapakṣasyaivānubhavasiddhatvādabādhitatvācca satyatvamiti
analyzed: sat samprayoge puruṣasya indriyāṇām buddhi janma tat pratyakṣam  iti atas nirākāra pakṣasya eva anubhava siddha tvāt abādhita tvāt ca satya tvam iti
translated: The arising of cognition in a person through the contact of the self and the senses is perception.🔽Thus, since the view of formlessness is established by experience and is also unobstructed, it is true.

analyzed: sa ākāra pakṣaḥ bhrāntaḥ eva iti atas ca muktau advaya asiddhiḥ iti upasaṃhāraḥ
translated: And since the view of form is mistaken, therefore the conclusion is that there is no establishment of non-eternality even in liberation.

analyzed: nanu evam api kṣaṇika tve iva akṣaṇika tve pi grāhyasya
translated: Even so, in the case of non-momentariness of the object grasped,

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt  kṣaṇikatva akṣaṇikatva sandehāt api upaplava rūpam iti akṣaṇikatve
translated: like momentariness, there is absence of proof.

analyzed: pramāṇam āha
translated: Even due to doubt about momentariness and non-momentariness, it is like an illusion. Therefore, in the case of non-momentariness, he states the proof.

analyzed: pratyabhijñānāt vyabhicāre tu sati api
translated: Therefore, even in the case of error in recognition,

original: sthairyaṃ kvacid gṛhītaṃ yat svabhāvatvena vastunaḥ // //
analyzed: sthairyam kvacid gṛhītam yat svabhāva tvena vastunaḥ
translated: the stability of an object somewhere is grasped as its nature.

analyzed: na kevalam prak pradarśi tanayena grāhaka ātmani eva sthairyam
translated: Not only is stability in the cognizing self shown by the previously demonstrated method,

original: yāvattadgrāhye'pi arthe pratyabhijñānāditi ayaṃ ghaṭaḥ iti
analyzed: yāvat tad grāhye api arthe pratyabhijñānāt iti ayam ghaṭaḥ iti
translated: but also in the object grasped, due to recognition. This is a pot.

analyzed: sthira tvena eva adhyavasāyāt nahi bhavadbhiḥ api adhyavasīyamānam
translated: Because it is ascertained as stable. For you cannot deny the stability

analyzed: sthairyam artheṣu apahnotum śakyam iti darśitam prāk eva nanu
translated: that is ascertained in objects, as shown before. But

analyzed: lūna punar jāteṣu iva keśa nakha ādiṣu sādṛśya nibandhanā
translated: As in the case of hair and nails, etc., which are cut and grow again, the notion of permanence will be based on similarity.

original: sthairyapratipattirbhaviṣyati ityāha kvacid bādhakabalāt vyabhicāre tu
analyzed: sthairya pratipattiḥ bhaviṣyati iti āha kvacid bādhaka balāt vyabhicāre tu
translated: But when there is an exception due to the force of a contradictory cognition,

analyzed: sati api anyatra abādhite viṣaye sati arajate rajata adhyavasāyasya eva
translated: even when the object is not contradicted elsewhere, the cognition of silver in what is really silver is not contradicted,

original: bādhakābhāvādavyabhicāraḥ / atrāpi bādhakaṃ pramāṇaṃ bhaviṣyatīti🔽cet / na / asaṃbhavādityāha gṛhītaṃ yat iti / yasmādidaṃ sthairyaṃ
analyzed: bādhaka abhāvāt avyabhicāraḥ atra api bādhakam pramāṇam bhaviṣyati iti  ced na asaṃbhavāt iti āha gṛhītam yat iti yasmāt idam sthairyam
translated: because there is no contradictory cognition. If it is argued that a contradictory cognition will arise in this case too,🔽[the answer is:] no, because it is impossible. He says, What is apprehended... Since this permanence is apprehended by perception that grasps the object, just like blue, etc.,

original: vastugrahiṇā pratyakṣeṇa nīlādivat prāggṛhītameva / agṛhīte hi🔽vasturūpe'dhyavasite śuktikārajatāderiva🔽keśanakhasthairyādhyavasāyasya bādho bhavatyeva / na tu gṛhīte
analyzed: vastu grahiṇā pratyakṣeṇa nīla ādi vat prāk gṛhītam eva agṛhīte hi  vastu rūpe idhi avasite śuktikā rajata ādeḥ iva  keśa nakha sthairya adhyavasāyasya bādhaḥ bhavati eva na tu gṛhīte
translated: it is already apprehended. For if the form of the object were not apprehended,🔽the cognition of the permanence of hair and nails, like the cognition of silver in a shell,

analyzed: nīla adhyavasāyasya iva anavasthā prasaṅgāt nanu  sthairyasya aneka kāla vyāpāra ātmaka tva dvartamāna mātra grāhiṇā
translated: would certainly be contradicted. But it is not, just like the cognition of blue, because that would lead to an infinite regress. But is it not the case

original: pratyakṣeṇa grahaṇaṃ na sambhavati / ityāha svabhāvatvena vastunaḥ iti /
analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa grahaṇam na sambhavati iti āha svabhāva tvena vastunaḥ iti
translated: that permanence, being of the nature of activity extending over many times, cannot be apprehended by perception that grasps only the present? He says, The object is grasped by its own nature...

analyzed: sthairyam api vastu svabhāva ātmakam eva tad asvabhāva tvena
translated: Stability also is of the nature of the essence of a thing itself. Because that [stability] is not the nature of a thing,

analyzed: vastunaḥ tad anupatteḥ praṇālikā agra niryat tvarita jala pravāha vat
translated: that [stability] does not follow from the thing, like the rapid flow of water emerging from the spout of a water pot.

original: pratikṣaṇavinaśyadrūpameva sarvaṃ vastu dṛṣṭaṃ syāt iti
analyzed: prati kṣaṇa vinaśyat rūpam eva sarvam vastu dṛṣṭam syāt iti
translated: All things would be seen as having a nature that perishes every moment.

analyzed: pratyakṣa virodhaḥ sthira ātma tayā eva vastunaḥ grahaṇāt tat uktam
translated: There is a contradiction with perception, because a thing is grasped precisely as having a stable nature. This is stated:

original: rajataṃ gṛhyamāṇaṃ hi cirasthāyīti gṛhyate / iti /
analyzed: rajatam gṛhyamāṇam hi cira sthāyi iti gṛhyate iti
translated: When silver is being grasped, it is grasped as lasting for a long time.

original: na ca sadṛśaparāparotpatteḥ sthairyapratipattirbhrānteti yujyata iti
analyzed: na ca sadṛśa para apara utpatteḥ sthairya pratipattiḥ bhrāntā iti yujyate iti
translated: And it is not proper to say that the understanding of stability due to the arising of similar things in succession is a delusion,

original: vaktuṃ tasyāpi asiddheḥ siddhe hi kṣaṇikatve kadācidetadupapadyate /
analyzed: vaktum tasya api asiddheḥ siddhe hi kṣaṇika tve kadācid etat upapadyate
translated: because that [stability] is also unestablished. For when momentariness is established, this [understanding of stability] is possible.

original: taccādyayāvat kimātmakaṃ kena kena pramāṇena siddhamiti na kasyacit
analyzed: tat ca adya yāvat kimātmakam kena kena pramāṇena siddham iti na kasyacid
translated: And that [momentariness] is not established by any [means of knowledge]. What is its nature? By what means of knowledge is it established? It is not established for anyone.

original: siddham / na ca vastusvabhāvo'pi vastuni gṛhīte na gṛhīta iti śakyaṃ
analyzed: siddham na ca vastu svabhāvaḥ api vastuni gṛhīte na gṛhītaḥ iti śakyam
translated: And it cannot be said that even the nature of a thing is not grasped when a thing is grasped,

analyzed: vaktum abhedāt yat uktam bhavadbhiḥ api
translated: because of non-difference. This is also stated by you:

analyzed: ekasya artha svabhāvasya pratyakṣasya sataḥ svayam
translated: Of a single existent thing, which has the nature of an object and is perceived by itself,

original: ko'nyo na dṛṣṭo bhāgaḥ syādyaḥ pramāṇaiḥ parīkṣyate //
analyzed: kaḥ nyaḥ na dṛṣṭaḥ bhāgaḥ syāt yaḥ pramāṇaiḥ parīkṣyate
translated: what other part is there that is not seen, which is examined by the means of knowledge?

original: iti nāpi ca pratyakṣaṃ vartamānamātragrāhitasyāpi sthirātmakatvāt /
analyzed: iti nā api ca pratyakṣam vartamāna mātra grāhitasya api sthira ātmaka tvāt
translated: Nor is it perception, because even that which grasps only the present is of a stable nature.

analyzed: indriya artha sannikarṣaḥ tu vartamānaḥ na pratyakṣaḥ ūrthaḥ tad saṃvid vā
translated: The contact of sense and object is present, but the object or its cognition is not perceived.

analyzed: ātma svabhāva tvāt tasyāḥ iti pratipāditam
translated: Because it is of the nature of the self, as has been explained.

analyzed: etat eva darśayati
translated: He shows this very thing:

original: bhūyo bhūyo hi yo'rthātmā gṛhyate tvekayā dhiyā /
analyzed: bhūyas bhūyas hi yaḥ ṛtha ātmā gṛhyate tu ekayā dhiyā
translated: When the nature of an object is grasped again and again by a single cognition,

original: yadā tadā ca tatsthairyaṃ brūta kena nivāryate // //🔽evaṃ hi bodhisattvānāmapi punaḥ punardṛśyamāneṣu
analyzed: yadā tadā ca tat sthairyam brūta kena nivāryate  evam hi bodhisattvānām api punar punar dṛśyamāneṣu
translated: then, by whom is its stability prevented?

analyzed: jāyā jananī ādiṣu artheṣu guru dāsa ādiṣu ca anurūpaḥ vyavahāra
translated: Thus, even in the case of the Bodhisattvas, when wives, mothers, etc., and preceptors, servants, etc., are seen again and again,

original: upapadyate'nyathā viparyaya eva syāt / nanu santānasya jananītvaṃ
analyzed: upapadyate nyathā viparyayaḥ eva syāt nanu santānasya jananī tvam
translated: a suitable usage is possible, otherwise there would be just the opposite. If it is argued that the continuity is the producer,

original: jāyārūpatā veti cet / na / tasyāpi santānivyatirekeṇa vastuto'sambhavāt
analyzed: jāyā rūpa tā vā iti ced na tasya api santāni vyatirekeṇa vastutas sambhavāt
translated: and the wife is of that form, no (it is not so). Because that also, apart from the continuity, is not possible as a substance.

original: santāninaḥ kṣaṇasyaiva jananītvaṃ yato jātaḥ tasyaivābhyupagantavyam /
analyzed: santāninaḥ kṣaṇasya eva jananī tvam yatas jātaḥ tasya eva abhyupagantavyam
translated: The producer of the moment of the continuity should be accepted as the mother of that which is born from it.

original: tataḥ pañcamasya tu kṣaṇasya pañcamīṃ mātṛbandhubhyaḥ iti
analyzed: tatas pañcamasya tu kṣaṇasya pañcamīm mātṛ bandhubhyaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, for the fifth moment, the fifth (mother) is from the maternal relatives, and so on.

analyzed: samācārāt jāyā tvam bhavat aviruddham eva syāt iti jitam
translated: The fact of being a wife is not incompatible with good conduct, so you are defeated.

original: dadhyutpāde kṣīrasya kiṃ jātaṃ yena tannopalabhyate / bālabhāṣitametat

The great thinkers consider this itself to be the relation of original and modification. People also say that milk which has disappeared has become curd. But when curd is produced, what happens to the milk that it is not perceived? This is the talk of a child.
